name: Hinamatsuri
description: Doll Festival, celebrating the health and happiness of girls.

name: Gion Matsuri
description: One of the most famous festivals in Japan, held in Kyoto.

name: Obon
description: A Buddhist festival to honor the spirits of ancestors.

name: Shichi-Go-San
description: A festival for children aged three, five, and seven.

name: Winter Peony Exhibition
description: Exhibition of winter peonies at Ueno Toshogu Shrine.

name: Ippan Sanga
description: New Year congratulatory visit by the general public to the Imperial Palace.

name: Kakizome
description: The first calligraphy of the year at Budokan.

name: Daikoku Matsuri
description: Festival dedicated to Daikoku, the god of wealth.

name: Kagami Biraki Budokan
description: Ceremonial cutting and eating of Kagami mochi.

name: Genpuku Shiki (Coming of Age)
description: Reenactment of coming-of-age ceremony.

name: Usokae
description: Bullfinch exchange festival at Kameido Tenjin Shrine.

name: Daruma Ichi Takahata
description: Fair selling daruma dolls for good luck.

name: All Japan Nishikigoi Prize Show
description: Showcase of Nishikigoi (koi fish).

name: Oni Matsuri
description: A festival featuring the traditional demon masks and rituals to ward off evil.

name: Shunsetsu (Chinese New Year Days)
description: Shunsetsu means Spring Festival. History of Chinatown in Yokohama begins with Japan's opening of Yokohama port to foreigners in 1859. Today it is the largest Chinatown in Japan. Every year about 18 million tourists visit the town. Streets and tangled alleys include more than 200 restaurants and over 300 shops which market Chinese products. Highlight of the festivity includes a fantastic parade of people in traditional wardrobes accompanied by dragon dances and lion dances.

name: Koishikawa Korakuen Ume Matsuri
description: A festival celebrating the blooming of ume (plum) trees in Koishikawa Korakuen, which features a central pond and hills, making it perfect for a stroll.

name: Kawazu Sakura Matsuri
description: The Kawazu-zakura cherry blossoms are famous for being some of the earliest-blooming cherry blossoms in Japan, with large pink flowers that bloom for about a month.

name: Winter Peony Exhibition
description: An exhibition showcasing winter peonies at Ueno Toshogu Shrine, famous for its Kan-botan (winter peonies).

name: Kameido Tenjin Ume Matsuri
description: A festival celebrating the ume blossoms at Kameido Tenjin Shrine, which enshrines Sugawara Michizane, a god of learning.

name: Mito Kairakuen Ume Matsuri
description: A festival held in Kairakuen, one of the three most famous parks in Japan, featuring about 3,000 plum trees.

name: Ta-asobi (Fertility festival or Rice field ritual)
description: A traditional ceremony reenacting the various tasks of rice production to pray for a plentiful harvest.

name: Katsuura Hina Matsuri (Doll Festival)
description: A festival for girls where traditional Hina Dolls are displayed, celebrating the Hina Matsuri on March 3.

name: Setsubun Bean Throwings
description: A traditional ceremony held at various temples and shrines to drive out evil spirits and welcome good fortune.

name: Hinamatsuri
description: A festival celebrating the health and happiness of girls, featuring the display of ornamental dolls.

name: Oni Matsuri
description: A festival where people dress as demons and participate in various activities to ward off evil spirits.

name: Mito Kairakuen Ume Matsuri
description: Every year about one million people visit the city for the festival. Kairakuen in Mito was a landscape gardening project started by Nariaki Tokugawa. The park opened in July 1842. In early spring, about 100 different types of 3,000 plum trees put flowers, making Kairakuen one of the three most famous parks of Japan.

name: Hinamatsuri
description: Doll Festival - Festival for Girls. Nearly 1,000 years ago, there was a custom as a seasonal event, children's dolls are specially displayed in the home, and games played, stories told and a feast given.

name: Katsuura Hina Matsuri
description: 1,200 traditional Hina Dolls are placed on the 60 steps of the Toomisaki Shrine in Katsuura City, Chiba Prefecture. 25,000 hina dolls sent from all over Japan decorate the entire city.

name: Bokutei Sakura Matsuri
description: Cherry Blossoms Festival along the Riverbank of the Sumida River, Mukojima, Sumida-ku. The Mukojima geishas serve tea to cherry blossom viewers on weekends.

name: Ueno Cherry Blossoms Festival
description: Ueno Park is probably the most well known cherry blossom viewing spot in Tokyo and it is most crowded.

name: Yasukuni Sakura Matsuri
description: Yasukuni Shrine offers entertainments for its sakura festival during the period.

name: Asakusa Children's Kabuki
description: Children's kabuki is played at many places in Japan and its history is long. Many teams selected from around the Kanto district join this event.

name: Naka-Meguro Sakura Matsuri
description: Lanterns will be decorated along the Meguro River for two weeks from the day Tokyo Meteorological Agency announces the opening of Sakura in Tokyo.

name: Tatebayashi Koinobori Matsuri
description: Along and over the Tsuruuda River, numerous carp streamers are flown to wish for good growth for boys.

name: Takayama Spring Festival
description: A festival featuring beautifully decorated floats and traditional performances.

name: Ueno Sakura Matsuri
description: A cherry blossom festival held in Ueno Park, one of the most popular hanami spots in Tokyo.

name: Gyoki-daie Zojoji Temple
description: A Buddhist devotion event commemorating the death of Honen, featuring a parade of priests.

name: Wisteria Festival Kameido Tenjin Shrine
description: A festival celebrating the blooming of wisteria flowers at Kameido Tenjin Shrine.

name: Hana Matsuri (Buddha's Birthday) Gokokuji Temple
description: A celebration of Buddha's birthday with various ceremonies and rituals.

name: Kanamara (Penis) Matsuri
description: A fertility festival held at Kanayama Shrine, featuring a parade and various rituals.

name: Peony Festival Ueno Toshogu Shrine
description: A festival showcasing various peony flowers at Ueno Toshogu Shrine.

name: Oiran Dochu
description: A reenacted parade of oiran courtesans from the Edo Era.

name: Shirasagi no Mai
description: A traditional dance performed at Sensoji Temple in Asakusa.

name: Yasukuni Shrine Hono Sumo
description: An exhibition of sumo matches held at Yasukuni Shrine.

name: Annual Spring Festival of Yasukuni Shrine
description: A festival honoring those who fought and died for Japan.

name: Noge Street Performances
description: A street performance festival featuring various acts and performances.

name: Konkon Kutsu Ichi Tamahime Shrine
description: A festival held at Tamahime Shrine to celebrate shoes and footwear.

name: Confucian Festival at Yushima Seido
description: A festival dedicated to Confucius with various offerings and ceremonies.

name: Aoi Matsuri
description: A traditional festival held in Kyoto, featuring a procession of people dressed in ancient court attire.

name: Kamo Matsuri
description: A festival dedicated to the Kamo deities, celebrated with a procession and various rituals.

name: Mashiko Pottery Fair
description: The pottery fair or festival at Mashiko started in 1966. It is held two times a year in spring during the Golden Week holidays (late April to early May) and in autumn in November. Approximately 500 tents dealers and about 50 permanent pottery stores line the main street of Mashiko's Jonaizaka Street for about 500 meters. Mashiko potteries are sold from traditional Mashiko earthen wares such as daily necessities cups and dishes to artistic pottery products.

name: Meiji Jingu Shrine Annual Spring Festival
description: The shrine is dedicated to the memory of the Emperor Meiji and his wife Empress Shoken. The festival includes various ceremonies and performances.

name: Ome Taisai
description: This is the festival of Sumiyoshi Shrine in Ohme City. On May 2, twelve festival floats parade their towns and all floats gather in front of JR Ome Station after three p.m. On May 3, twelve floats parade along the Ome Kaido street.

name: Kurayami Matsuri
description: A festival at Okunitama Shrine in Fuchu, where the mikoshi (portable shrine) is paraded at midnight after all city lights are turned off.

name: Giant Kite Festival
description: The origin of the festival goes back to 1841 when a Buddhism priest told the village people about a kite flying to pray for a bumper harvest.

name: Kazo's Jumbo Koinobori
description: Kazo City produces about 50% of koinobori in Japan. The giant koinobori is about 100 meters long and weighs 350 kilograms.

name: Omiya Bonsai Festival
description: A festival celebrating bonsai culture in Omiya Bonsai Village, featuring over 100 bonsai shops.

name: Teppozu Inari Grand Festival
description: A major festival year with town mikoshi parading.

name: Karasumori Inari Grand Festival
description: A major festival year with a huge mikoshi of Karasumori Shrine parading.

name: Kachiya Festival
description: Features a parade of Samurai warriors in armors commemorating Fujiwara Hidesato.

name: Sanja Matsuri
description: One of the three big shrine festivals of Tokyo, known for its wild and large scale.

name: Nikko Toshogu Spring Festival
description: Includes yabusame (horseback archery) and a procession of 1,000 Samurai.

name: Shitaya Shrine Grand Festival
description: A popular early summer event in downtown Ueno.

name: Yushima Tenjin Grand Festival
description: A major festival year with a parade of shrine mikoshi.

name: Hanazono Shrine Grand Festival
description: A major festival year with a grand parade.

name: Gion Matsuri
description: One of the most famous festivals in Japan, featuring a parade of floats and various events throughout the month.

name: Tanabata
description: A festival celebrating the meeting of two stars, often marked by colorful decorations and wishes written on strips of paper.

name: Obon
description: A Buddhist festival honoring the spirits of ancestors, featuring dances and lanterns.

name: Shobu Matsuri
description: Festival celebrating the blooming of irises at Horikiri Shobuen.

name: Sanno Matsuri Jinkosai Parade
description: Parade as part of the Sanno Matsuri festival.

name: Tenno-sai of Susanoo Shrine
description: Annual festival dedicated to the Shinto god Susanoo.

name: Tenno-sai Festival at Shinagawa Shrine
description: Festival at Shinagawa Shrine featuring various town mikoshis.

name: Tenno-sai Festival at Ebara Shrine
description: Festival at Ebara Shrine featuring a unique mikoshi with a mask of Susanoo.

name: Tsukiji Shishi Matsuri
description: Annual festival at Tsukiji Namiyoke Shrine.

name: Hoozuki Ichi
description: Fair featuring the Chinese lantern plant.

name: Oyama-biraki
description: Mountain opening ceremony for Mt. Fuji.

name: Bunkyo Ajisai Matsuri
description: Hydrangea festival at Hakusan Jinja Shrine.

name: Night Festival of Torigoe Shrine
description: Night festival featuring a heavy mikoshi and lanterns.

name: Gujo Odori in Aoyama
description: Bon odori dance event open to everyone.

name: Gion Matsuri
description: One of the most famous festivals in Japan, featuring elaborate floats and traditional events.

name: Tenjin Matsuri
description: A festival dedicated to the deity of learning, featuring a river procession and fireworks.

name: Kappabashi Shitamachi Tanabata Matsuri
description: A festival celebrating the Tanabata, featuring various attractions and parades.

name: Hiratsuka Tanabata Matsuri
description: A large Tanabata festival in Hiratsuka, Kanagawa Prefecture, which began after WWII.

name: Narita Gion Matsuri
description: A summer festival in Narita City, featuring a parade of floats.

name: Iriya Asagao Ichi Taito
description: A morning glory fair held at Iriya Kishibojin Temple, marking the arrival of summer.

name: Ose no Shishimai
description: A festival held at Hikawa Shrine in Ose, featuring traditional lion dances.

name: Kuki's Chochin Matsuri
description: A lantern festival held at Yakumo Shrine in Kuki, featuring parades and displays.

name: Yasukuni Shrine Mitama Matsuri
description: A festival honoring the spirits of the war dead, featuring various traditional performances.

name: Satte Summer Festival
description: A summer festival in Satte City featuring parades of floats.

name: Kumagaya Uchiwa Matsuri
description: A festival in Kumagaya City, originally a ceremony for protection from epidemics.

name: Edogawa-ku Kingyo Matsuri
description: A festival celebrating goldfish, featuring exhibitions and sales.

name: Doyo no Ushino Hi (Eel Eating Day)
description: A traditional day for eating eels, believed to provide vitality during summer.

name: Kawasaki Daishi Fu-rin Ichi
description: The largest wind-bell fair in Japan, featuring various wind chimes.

name: Ueno Summer Festival
description: A festival showcasing various Japanese festivals, though no parade this year.

name: Hanabi Taikai (Fireworks Festivals)
description: Fireworks festivals held in various locations, including Sumida River.

name: Iriya Morning Glory Festival
description: An exhibition of giant morning glories held in Hibiya Park.

name: Haneda Shrine Annual Festival
description: A festival featuring a parade of mikoshis in Haneda.

name: Tanabata
description: A festival celebrating the meeting of two stars, Orihime and Hikoboshi, held on the seventh day of the seventh month of the lunar calendar.

name: Obon
description: A Buddhist festival honoring the spirits of ancestors, typically celebrated with dances and lanterns.

name: Bon Odori at Tsukiji Honganji
description: Bon Odori (Bon Dance) was originally danced in honor of the dead during the O-Bon season. The dance varies according to the district, but the general features are that the participants assemble at temples or the village common, form a circle and dance round to the music of flutes and drums.

name: Hachioji Matsuri
description: Hachioji Matsuri (Festival) is the largest festival of Hachioji City located in the western suburbs of Tokyo. The festival is held from the first Friday of August for three days every year.

name: Matsudo Fireworks Taikai
description: A fireworks festival held in Matsudo.

name: Bon Odori at Ikegami Honmonji
description: Bon Odori (Bon Dance) is danced in honor of the dead during the O-Bon season.

name: Asagaya Tanabata Matsuri
description: A festival featuring colorful decorations of Tanabata paper streamers and giant papier-mache characters.

name: Kiraigo Chiba
description: A unique Buddhism drama which has a long history of 800 years.
location: Kosaiji Temple, Musho Village, Yokoshiba, Chiba Prefecture

name: Kugenuma Kou Daijingu Festival
description: A festival featuring traditional floats and performances.

name: Takasaki Matsuri
description: A festival featuring dashi floats and various entertainments.

name: Edogawa Hanabi Taikai
description: A fireworks display at the Edogawa River.

name: Minami Koshigaya Awa Odori
description: Awa Odori dance festival featuring various teams.

name: Azabu Juban Noryo Matsuri
description: A summer festival featuring outdoor stalls and performances.

name: Harajuku Super Yosakoi
description: A festival featuring Yosakoi dance performances.

name: Koenji Awa Odori
description: A large Awa Odori festival with many dancers and groups.

name: Tachikawa Suwa Shrine Festival
description: A festival featuring a mikoshi parade and various performances.

name: Kanto Matsuri
description: A festival featuring large floats and traditional performances.

name: Oni Matsuri
description: A festival celebrating the local folklore with traditional dances and rituals.

name: Kitazawa Hachiman Shrine Festival
description: The festival features Japanese drums, Mikomai, Ohayashi, Ryukyu Dance, and Bugaku performances, with a highlight of over 20 town mikoshis entering the shrine.

name: Nogi Shrine Annual Festival
description: Shinto ritual ceremony held on the day of General Maresuke Nogi's death, with a memorial service at Aoyama Cemetery.

name: Kichijoji Autumn Festival
description: Kichijoji's biggest event featuring a parade of shrine mikoshi and town mikoshis.

name: Ishioka Festival
description: A spectacular festival featuring horojishi floats and parades, attracting over 400,000 spectators.

name: Asakusa Samba Festival
description: A vibrant samba festival held in Asakusa, reviving the entertainment district's liveliness.

name: Tsurugaoka Hachimangu Reitaisai Festival
description: Features a jinkosai parade and Yabusame (horseback archery) events.

description: Jinkosai Parade featuring floats and mikoshi.

description: Celebration of the Hagi plant, with performances and tea ceremonies.

name: Cosmos Flower Festival
description: A festival showcasing cosmos flowers at Showa Memorial Park.

name: Moon Viewing at Mukojima Hyakkaen
description: Traditional moon viewing event with offerings and performances.

name: Ohara Hadaka (Naked Man) Matsuri
description: A valiant festival featuring mikoshi carried by 'naked' men into the sea.

name: Higan (Autumn Equinox Day)
description: A Buddhist memorial service period for visiting family cemeteries.

name: Shusse no Ishidan Festival
description: Mikoshi carrying event up and down the steep stone steps of the shrine.

name: Shinagawa Shukuba Matsuri
description: A festival celebrating the history of Shinagawa as a post town with parades.

name: Kanto Matsuri
description: A festival featuring large floats and traditional performances.

name: Awa Odori
description: A traditional dance festival held in Tokushima.

name: Jidai Matsuri
description: A historical festival showcasing the history of Kyoto.

name: Shichi-Go-San
description: A festival celebrating the growth of children aged 3, 5, and 7.

name: Ekota-no-Shishimai Hikawa Shrine
description: Lion Dance of Ekota at Hikawa Shrine in Ekota, Nakano-ku.

name: Kappabashi Dougu Matsuri
description: Kappabashi Dougu Matsuri from Oct. 8 to Oct. 14 in 2024.

name: Sawara-no-Taisai
description: Grand Festival of Sawara on Oct. 11, 12, and 13.

name: Tokyo Yosakoi
description: Tokyo Yosakoi at Ikebukuro on Oct. 12 and 13.

name: Ikegami Honmonji Temple Oeshiki Ceremony
description: Oeshiki at Ikegami Honmonji on Oct. 12.

name: Kanuma Autumn Festival
description: Kanuma Autumn Festival on Oct. 12 and 13.

name: Sakura Autumn Festival
description: Sakura Autumn Festival on Oct. 12 and 13.

name: Oedo Mikoshi Matsuri
description: Oedo Mikoshi Matsuri on Oct. 13.

name: Nikko Toshogu Annual Autumn Festival - Yabusame
description: Nikko Toshogu Annual Autumn Festival - Yabusame on Oct. 16.

name: Yasukuni Shrine Autumn Festival Tokyo
description: Annual Autumn Festival of Yasukuni Shrine from Oct. 17 to 19.

name: Halloween
description: Halloween gathering at Shibuya on Oct. 31.

name: Shichi-Go-San
description: A traditional rite of passage for children aged three, five, and seven.

name: Meiji Jingu Shrine Autumn Grand Festival
description: Various events are held preceding the official day of the festival days. The shrine is dedicated to the memory of the Emperor Meiji and his wife Empress Shoken.

name: Hibiya Park Chrysanthemum Exhibition
description: The exhibition is one of the largest and known for its high standard. About 2,000 items are displayed.

name: Yushima Tenjin Chrysanthemum Matsuri
description: Chrysanthemum (kiku) which originally came from China was extensively cultivated in Japan and surpassed far in beauty than the chrysanthemum in China.

name: Mt Takao Autumn Leaves Festival
description: Visitors can enjoy its natural beauty and many other attractions all in a day's trip.

name: Tochigi Autumn Festival
description: The festival is held every other year. The festival in 2024 will be on Nov. 1,2 and 3.

name: Honjoh Matsuri
description: The festival is the event of Kanasana Shrine. Highlight of the festival comes on Nov. 3.

name: Dream Yosakoi
description: The energetic dance - combination of traditional Japanese dance and modern music did not take time to attract people's attentions.

name: Hakone Daimyo Gyoretsu
description: Daimyo Gyoretsu parade is held on November 3 at Hakone Yumoto, a hot spring town of Hakone.

name: Shirasagi-no-Mai
description: The dance was a ritual of Shintoism and has its roots in the Gion Festival of Yasaka Shrine in Kyoto.

name: Air Self Defense Force Iruma Air Show
description: Iruma Air Base is today known widely among Japanese people as a base where JASDF's aviation team Blue Impulse performs acrobatic flights.

name: Tori no Ichi Asakusa
description: People of downtown Tokyo feel the year is close to an end when tori-no-ichi comes.

name: Doburoku Matsuri
description: The shrine offers new wheat and 'doburoku' (unrefined raw sake) to God and Kagura-mai (sacred dance) is performed before God.

name: Issa Matsuri
description: Haiku Master Kobayashi Issa wrote haiku poems in a very personal, simple style.

name: New Year’s Day
description: Celebration of the New Year with various traditional customs.

name: Chichibu Yomatsuri
description: A famous night festival featuring floats and fireworks, held in Chichibu City.

name: Ako Gishisai Festival

name: Hagoita Ichi
description: A fair selling hagoita (Japanese battledores) held at Sensoji Temple.

description: A winter solstice festival held at Ana Hachiman Shrine.

description: By burning the good-luck charms you have used the past year in a holy flame and bathing in the heat...

description: A traditional festival celebrated in Koto City, Tokyo.

description: A Tanabata festival celebrated in Fussa City, Tokyo.

description: A summer night festival with lantern floating in Koto City, Tokyo.

description: A festival for warding off evil held in Setagaya City, Tokyo.

description: A ginger root festival held in Minato City, Tokyo.

description: A traditional harvest festival held at Shinagawa Shrine.

name: Niiname-sai at Meiji Shrine
description: A traditional harvest festival held at Meiji Shrine.

description: A market held at Otori Shrine.

name: Annual Festival at Otori Shrine / Tori no Ichi Market (San no Tori)
description: An annual festival held at Otori Shrine.

name: Tsubaki Festival of Izu Oshima Island
description: A festival celebrating the camellia flower.

name: Shimokita Tengu Matsuri
description: A festival celebrating the Tengu, a mythical creature.

description: A ceremony honoring the Daruma doll.
